titleStmt.title: Verses written 30 Years agoe1By James Moore Smith Esq;. as I have since discovered.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: \f.56r; transcribed line for line\But that this Cover might not be altogetherFilled with my own slight productions I haveinserted a little piece that must have beenwritten at least 30 Years ago; & which has spirit, if not truth.────It was found theother day in a drawer in my Lord Sussex'sLibrary, which had never been opened since\f.56v\ the death of his Father\ins·.·del·which happened·something·del·?ago, as I have·something del\.────If it had falleninto the hands of some ill-natured persons, whowould have altered the names in the last lineto \del·(Gray) and (Mason) and·½ line scrawled out·it·\½ line scrawled out two the two odes on obscuri-ty and oblivion\:──The publick, \1½ lines scrawled out\would possibly have swall'owed the piece downglibly, as a new production\ins·.·del and possibly \del·would·ins·might\not have thought the Satire too much over-charged·½ line scrawled out·might havecontributed to·½ line scrawled out of the one of·½ line scrawled out·, if the other·word deleted·?be ?thought·1½ lines scrawled out\ of beingraised].
Behold the monarch Oaks, that rise
With lofty branches to the skies
Have huge proportion'd roots, which grow
With equal longitude below
Two bards, who now in fashion reign
Most aptly this device explain
If this with Clouds & stars will venture
That creeps, as far beneath the Center.
More to explain the thing I mean
Have you not in a saw-pit seen
A skill'd Mechanic, who has stood
On a Faln pyramid of wood
And hir'd a subterraneous deletedan friend
To take his Iron by the end
But which excelled was never found
The Man above or under ground.f.57vThe Moral is so pat and Fit
That were I but the God of wit
Then in a saw-pit in wet weather
Should Young & Phillips work together.393-283L
